{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3159145,"name":"6366 Scott Wheeler Programming Mentor","username":"Robocoder2","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/r/71c47a/{size}.png","created_at":"2023-03-07T13:36:41.072Z","cooked":"

We are using the Spark max velocity control example for our drive base code. We have 4 Neo’s, 2 on left side with one following, and 2 on right side with one following. We are reaching set point just fine, current PID settings P=.000006, I=0, D=0, F=.000015. Our issue is we want to decrease the acceleration/de acceleration. Would we use the Izone to do this task? If not, should we just add some D? What is the Izone setting for? we don’t see what this setting is used for.

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":10,"updated_at":"2023-03-07T13:36:41.072Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":609,"reads":180,"readers_count":179,"score":3081.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":429252,"topic_slug":"spark-max-velocity-control-izone","display_username":"6366 Scott Wheeler Programming Mentor","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":34291,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/spark-max-velocity-control-izone/429252/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3159152,"name":"2582","username":"chadr03","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/chadr03/{size}/195529_2.png","created_at":"2023-03-07T13:58:46.196Z","cooked":"

Since your I value is zero Izone should not do anything for you. The I portion of the PID controller basically increases with error over time and if you do not constrain it to a zone sometimes it can become a large value that causes unwanted instability. The Izone is essentially an error band that limits when the I value starts to accumulate.

I think the easiest way to limit your acceleration might be the closed loop ramp rate setting on the spark max.

setClosedLoopRampRate​(double rate)

Sets the ramp rate for closed loop control modes.

This is the maximum rate at which the motor controller’s output is allowed to change.

Parameters:
rate - Time in seconds to go from 0 to full throttle.

CANSparkMax (FRC-REVLib API) (revrobotics.com)

Otherwise you could use some sort of profiled pid controller either through the WPI profiledPIDController or the SmartMotion builtin on the Spark Max

Thx chader03! We’ll try the setCloseLoopRampRate setting tonight!

You can also use a SlewRateLimiter on the value passed into your Closed-Loop Setpoint

chadr03:

setClosedLoopRampRate​(double rate)

Do not use this. It interacts badly with feedback control.

Moreover, velocity closed-loop control on the SparkMAX is not very useful unless you modify the velocity filter settings and/or use an external controller.

I am vaguely aware of the issues surrounding Smart Motion and velocity control. Would creating a wpilib PID/feed forward controller, with a REV through bore encoder plugged into the spark max circumvent this? Or should we stay away from Spark Maxes entirely for velocity/position control? Or at least have the encoder bypass the Spark Max entirely and feed directly into the Rio?

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":10,"updated_at":"2023-03-07T15:28:06.574Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":5,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":96,"readers_count":95,"score":34.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":429252,"topic_slug":"spark-max-velocity-control-izone","display_username":"Michael DeVinney","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":3,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":12381,"username":"Oblarg","name":"Eli Barnett","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/oblarg/{size}/161674_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":32051,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"SoKno Robo Mentor Team 6517"},"post_url":"/t/spark-max-velocity-control-izone/429252/6","custom_user_title":"SoKno Robo Mentor Team 6517","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3159207,"name":"Eli Barnett","username":"Oblarg","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/oblarg/{size}/161674_2.png","created_at":"2023-03-07T15:23:48.135Z","cooked":"

Both of your suggested solutions will work, as will (potentially) just modifying the filter settings on the hall effect velocity reading. Make sure you still adjust the velocity filter settings on the SparkMax if you end up using an external encoder, because the defaults are still quite lagged.

Here are the results from our testing our drive train last night. The setCloseLoopRampRate worked perfect! All we had to do was adjust the time in seconds for acceleration/de acceleration. We also tried the SlewrateLimiter, but it seem to have no impact, not sure if we setup right so we went back to using the setCloseLoopRampRate. We are using integrated encoders on Neo’s and we couldn’t be happier with these results!

IIRC there’s the “smart velocity” mode on sparks that will ramp the setpoints but not the outputs.
